reasoning:
The critique targets a specific load-bearing step in §3.2: the move from (unbounded) linearity to separability/replicability and then to the “must capture most galaxies or lose ~all value” claim. If that bridge failed, it would weaken one of the paper’s main routes to concluding that plausible moral views are fussy. However, the paper also argues for “no easy eutopia” via other routes (fragility/product-of-factors, moral catastrophe examples, bounded-view analysis), so refuting this step would not collapse the overall thesis, hence moderate centrality.

On strength: the critique correctly notes that linearity in ‘resources for good’ does not automatically entail the kind of parcel-wise separability the paper uses, if value depends on global/relational properties (rights, legitimacy, non-domination) or on coordination mechanisms (incl. acausal trade) that can make “missing resources” not translate to proportional value loss. But the paper is explicitly analyzing “linear views” as separable at scale (essentially the standard utilitarian/additive picture), so the critique partly looks like a reclassification move (“those linear-but-nonseparable views exist”) rather than a direct refutation of the argument as applied to the intended class. It therefore weakens the generality of the conclusion about linear views, but doesn’t decisively refute it.

Relevance is fairly high because it engages a Tier-2 core claim in Forethought’s better-futures agenda (narrow target/fussiness) and points to an interaction/tension with mechanisms the paper itself raises (acausal trade; global constraints), potentially affecting how their EV decomposition over survival vs flourishing should treat ‘scale capture’.
title: "Linear Unbounded Theories Assume Separability that Undermines Their Own Mechanisms"
